text: CHAPTER I: OF GOLDEN WALTER AND HIS FATHER
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Awhile ago there was a young man dwelling in a great and goodly city by
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the sea which had to name Langton on Holm.   He was but of five and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: twenty winters, a fair-faced man, yellow-haired, tall and strong; rather
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: wiser than foolisher than young men are mostly wont; a valiant youth, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: a kind; not of many words but courteous of speech; no roisterer, nought
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: masterful, but peaceable and knowing how to forbear: in a fray a perilous
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: foe, and a trusty war-fellow.   His father, with whom he was dwelling
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: when this tale begins, was a great merchant, richer than a baron of the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: land, a head-man of the greatest of the Lineages of Langton, and a
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: captain of the Porte; he was of the Lineage of the Goldings, therefore
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: was he called Bartholomew Golden, and his son Golden Walter.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Now ye may well deem that such a youngling as this was looked upon by all
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: as a lucky man without a lack; but there was this flaw in his lot,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: whereas he had fallen into the toils of love of a woman exceeding fair,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and had taken her to wife, she nought unwilling as it seemed.   But when
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: they had been wedded some six months he found by manifest tokens, that
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: his fairness was not so much to her but that she must seek to the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: foulness of one worser than he in all ways; wherefore his rest departed
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: from him, whereas he hated her for her untruth and her hatred of him; yet
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: would the sound of her voice, as she came and went in the house, make his
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: heart beat; and the sight of her stirred desire within him, so that he
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: longed for her to be sweet and kind with him, and deemed that, might it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: be so, he should forget all the evil gone by.   But it was not so; for
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: ever when she saw him, her face changed, and her hatred of him became
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: manifest, and howsoever she were sweet with others, with him she was hard
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and sour.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: So this went on a while till the chambers of his father's house, yea the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: very streets of the city, became loathsome to him; and yet he called to
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: mind that the world was wide and he but a young man.   So on a day as he
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: sat with his father alone, he spake to him and said: "Father, I was on
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the quays even now, and I looked on the ships that were nigh boun, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: thy sign I saw on a tall ship that seemed to me nighest boun.   Will it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: be long ere she sail?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay," said his father, "that ship, which hight the Katherine, will they
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: warp out of the haven in two days' time.   But why askest thou of her?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "The shortest word is best, father," said Walter, "and this it is, that I
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: would depart in the said ship and see other lands."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea and whither, son?" said the merchant.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "Whither she goeth," said Walter, "for I am ill at ease at home, as thou
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: wottest, father."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: The merchant held his peace awhile, and looked hard on his son, for there
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: was strong love between them; but at last he said: "Well, son, maybe it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: were best for thee; but maybe also we shall not meet again."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "Yet if we do meet, father, then shalt thou see a new man in me."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said Bartholomew, "at least I know on whom to lay the loss of
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: thee, and when thou art gone, for thou shalt have thine own way herein,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: she shall no longer abide in my house.   Nay, but it were for the strife
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: that should arise thenceforth betwixt her kindred and ours, it should go
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat worse with her than that."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Said Walter: "I pray thee shame her not more than needs must be, lest, so
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: doing, thou shame both me and thyself also."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Bartholomew held his peace again for a while; then he said: "Goeth she
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: with child, my son?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Walter reddened, and said: "I wot not; nor of whom the child may be."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Then they both sat silent, till Bartholomew spake, saying: "The end of it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: is, son, that this is Monday, and that thou shalt go aboard in the small
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: hours of Wednesday; and meanwhile I shall look to it that thou go not
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: away empty-handed; the skipper of the Katherine is a good man and true,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and knows the seas well; and my servant Robert the Low, who is clerk of
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the lading, is trustworthy and wise, and as myself in all matters that
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: look towards chaffer.   The Katherine is new and stout-builded, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: should be lucky, whereas she is under the ward of her who is the saint
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: called upon in the church where thou wert christened, and myself before
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: thee; and thy mother, and my father and mother all lie under the chancel
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: thereof, as thou wottest."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith the elder rose up and went his ways about his business, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: there was no more said betwixt him and his son on this matter.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: CHAPTER II: GOLDEN WALTER TAKES SHIP TO SAIL THE SEAS
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: When Walter went down to the Katherine next morning, there was the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: skipper Geoffrey, who did him reverence, and made him all cheer, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: showed him his room aboard ship, and the plenteous goods which his father
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: had sent down to the quays already, such haste as he had made.  Walter
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: thanked his father's love in his heart, but otherwise took little heed to
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: his affairs, but wore away the time about the haven, gazing listlessly on
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the ships that were making them ready outward, or unlading, and the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: mariners and aliens coming and going: and all these were to him as the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: curious images woven on a tapestry.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: At last when he had wellnigh come back again to the Katherine, he saw
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: there a tall ship, which he had scarce noted before, a ship all-boun,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: which had her boats out, and men sitting to the oars thereof ready to tow
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: her outwards when the hawser should be cast off, and by seeming her
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: mariners were but abiding for some one or other to come aboard.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: So Walter stood idly watching the said ship, and as he looked, lo! folk
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: passing him toward the gangway.  These were three; first came a dwarf,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: dark-brown of hue and hideous, with long arms and ears exceeding great
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and dog-teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast.  He was clad
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: in a rich coat of yellow silk, and bare in his hand a crooked bow, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: was girt with a broad sax.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: After him came a maiden, young by seeming, of scarce twenty summers; fair
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: of face as a flower; grey-eyed, brown-haired, with lips full and red,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: slim and gentle of body.  Simple was her array, of a short and strait
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: green gown, so that on her right ankle was clear to see an iron ring.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Last of the three was a lady, tall and stately, so radiant of visage and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: glorious of raiment, that it were hard to say what like she was; for
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: scarce might the eye gaze steady upon her exceeding beauty; yet must
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: every son of Adam who found himself anigh her, lift up his eyes again
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: after he had dropped them, and look again on her, and yet again and yet
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: again.  Even so did Walter, and as the three passed by him, it seemed to
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: him as if all the other folk there about had vanished and were nought;
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: nor had he any vision before his eyes of any looking on them, save
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: himself alone.  They went over the gangway into the ship, and he saw them
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: go along the deck till they came to the house on the poop, and entered it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and were gone from his sight.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: There he stood staring, till little by little the thronging people of the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: quays came into his eye-shot again; then he saw how the hawser was cast
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: off and the boats fell to tugging the big ship toward the harbour-mouth
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: with hale and how of men.  Then the sail fell down from the yard and was
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: sheeted home and filled with the fair wind as the ship's bows ran up on
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the first green wave outside the haven.  Even therewith the shipmen cast
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: abroad a banner, whereon was done in a green field a grim wolf ramping up
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: against a maiden, and so went the ship upon her way.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Walter stood awhile staring at her empty place where the waves ran into
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the haven-mouth, and then turned aside and toward the Katherine; and at
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: concerning the said ship and her alien wayfarers; but then it came into
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: his mind, that all this was but an imagination or dream of the day, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: that he were best to leave it untold to any.  So therewith he went his
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: way from the water-side, and through the streets unto his father's house;
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the steps of stone and into the street; to wit the dwarf, the maiden, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: CHAPTER III: WALTER HEARETH TIDINGS OF THE DEATH OF HIS FATHER
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: Fast sailed the Katherine over the seas, and nought befell to tell of,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: either to herself or her crew.  She came to one cheaping-town and then to
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: another, and so on to a third and a fourth; and at each was buying and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: selling after the manner of chapmen; and Walter not only looked on the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: doings of his father's folk, but lent a hand, what he might, to help them
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: in all matters, whether it were in seaman's craft, or in chaffer.  And
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the further he went and the longer the time wore, the more he was eased
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: of his old trouble wherein his wife and her treason had to do.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: with those three, it yet flickered before him; and though he had not seen
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: them if he would, yet were their images often before his mind's eye; and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: Now swift sailed the Bartholomew for four weeks toward the north-west
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: At last the old chief arose and spake: "Ye men, here are come a man and a

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

text: she cometh, and of what lineage she may be?"

text: CHAPTER XXXVI: OF WALTER AND THE MAID IN THE DAYS OF THE KINGSHIP
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: the Maid to the King's chamber; and he met her, and took her by the
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: shoulders and kissed her, and said: "Art thou not weary, sweetheart?  Doth
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: not the city, and the thronging folk, and the watching eyes of the great
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: ones . . . doth it not all lie heavy on thee, as it doth upon me?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: She said: "And where is the city now? is not this the wilderness again,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: and thou and I alone together therein?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: He gazed at her eagerly, and she reddened, so that her eyes shone light
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: amidst the darkness of the flush of her cheeks.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: than the wilderness? is not the fear gone, yea, every whit thereof?"
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: The dark flush had left her face, and she looked on him exceeding
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: sweetly, and spoke steadily and clearly: "Even so it is, beloved."
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: wise men to the council; and first he bade open the prison-doors, and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: feed the needy and clothe them, and make good cheer to all men, high and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: matters, and they marvelled at his wisdom and the keenness of his wit;
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: lasted.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: tell no more; nor of how he saw Langton again, and his dealings there.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: In Stark-wall he dwelt, and reigned a King, well beloved of his folk,
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: sorely feared of their foemen.  Strife he had to deal with, at home and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: abroad; but therein he was not quelled, till he fell asleep fair and
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: softly, when this world had no more of deeds for him to do.  Nor may it
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: be said that the needy lamented him; for no needy had he left in his own
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: land.  And few foes he left behind to hate him.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: As to the Maid, she so waxed in loveliness and kindness, that it was a
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: year's joy for any to have cast eyes upon her in street or on field.  All
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: wizardry left her since the day of her wedding; yet of wit and wisdom she
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: had enough left, and to spare; for she needed no going about, and no
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: guile, any more than hard commands, to have her will done.  So loved she
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: was by all folk, forsooth, that it was a mere joy for any to go about her
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: errands.  To be short, she was the land's increase, and the city's
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: safeguard, and the bliss of the folk.
title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

text: might atone it.

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World
author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

text: World, in a short white coat alone, with bare feet and naked arms; but
title: The Wood Beyond the World

author: Morris, William

title: The Wood Beyond the World

author: Morris, William
